Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)

Discussing Solutions and Strategies

Discuss and explore students’ understanding by asking them to evaluate the expression for the dependent variable for a given value of the independent variable.

Suggested Questions

  • In the Initial Challenge, what is the discounted price if the original cost of the tour is $400? (C = $400 − $50 = $350) $360? (C = $360 − $50 = $310)
  • In What If . . . ? Situation B, what is the final discounted price if the purchase price was $305? (D = $305 − $20 = $285)

Discuss and explore students’ understanding by asking them how they used the equation to find the value of the independent variable when they were given the dependent variable.

  • In the Initial Challenge, what is the original cost of the tour if the discounted price is $275? ($275 = t − $50) 405? ($405 = t − $50)
  • In What If . . . ? Situation B, what is the purchase price if the final discounted price was $225? ($225 = P − $20)

Making the Mathematics Explicit

Help students discuss which representation (table, graph, or equation) is helpful to answer questions about the variables. (Agency, Identity, Ownership)

Suggested Questions

  • What equation made sense to you for the situation in the Initial Challenge? (C = P − $50)
  • How did you use the equation to find the cost for a $400 tour? (C = $400 − $50, so it is $350.)
  • How did you use the equation to find the original tour price if the customer paid $275? ($275 = P − $50. $325. Many students will guess and check while some may talk about using a fact family relationship knowing that $275 + $50 must equal the original price [P]. Students don’t need to be pushed to a formal way of solving equations at this point.)

Have students explain using Lisa’s equation strategy, Xavier’s table strategy, Mikala’s graph strategy, and Pat’s guess-and-check strategy for this situation. Have students show these ideas visually so that you can point out the connections.

When discussing What If . . . ? Situation B, look for examples from the students using tables, graphs, equations, and guess and check for answering the questions.

  • How can you use the equation to find the value of one variable when you are given the value of the other variable? (Answers will vary. This is just the introduction to solving equations. Accept all reasonable explanations. Some examples: You can use fact families. You can guess and check. You substitute the value of the given variable into the equation and then compute the value of the unknown variable.)
  • When does it make sense to use tables, graphs, or equations to find the value of a variable? (Answers will vary. At this point, it is important for students to see all as viable strategies.)

Now What Do Students Know?

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know? questions.

Reflecting on Student Learning

Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.

  • What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know? question?
    1. Where did my students get stuck?
    2. What strategies did they use?
    3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?
  • How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this unit? The next unit?
